item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu Pt. 2
item.description: Mina’hugua: Adingani i Lahi-hu I finene’na na blog guini. Buenas yan håfa adai todus hamyu! Åpmam na tiempu na månggi’ yu’ guini, hunggan? Gi minagåhet, gof tinani’ yu’ desde ki tåtti hugua na pulan. Kada diha hu ripiti ta’lu na bidå-hu: makmåta yu’ yan etsisiu pat chochu, pues macho’chu’, ya pues hugåndu yan i lahi-hu. Todu eyu ha tifi’ yu’, lol. I asunto put ini na blog kosa ki hu mås påtti hamyu ni taiminapput sinångan siha na hu sangåni i lahi-hu.

item.title: Mampus Chaddek i Lahi-hu
item.description: Kada diha, hu li’i’ malålagu i lahi-hu gi uriyan guma’-måmi. Gaigi gui’ gi me’nan potta, pues ha malågu hålum i kuatton-måmi, pues gaigi gui’ gi tatti yu’ pat fi’on-hu. Ai adai, guaha na biåhi ti siña hu sodda’ i tiempu para dumeskånsa. Lao gi minagåhet, eyu ha na’magof yu’ sa’ hu lili’i’ gui’ dumångkulu; mås chumachålek gui’, gof ya-ña humugågandu yan hami yan si Lorie asaguå-hu, ya bula kumukuentus gui’!

item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu
item.description: Talking To My Son A note: this is a modified post from when I was blogging on write.as. Most of the Chamoru that I’ve been using lately is towards i lahi-hu. Håcha na såkkan idåt-ña, pues inadingan-måmi ni ti mapput. I wanted to share some of those phrases with you and perhaps get some feedback. If you’re here then I’ll assume you came from Twitter, IG, or some other social media site.

item.title: I Tinituhon
item.description: Buenas yan håfa adai todus hamyu! Guahu i che’lun-miyu as David Taitingfong ya ini iyo-ku na blog ni’ un taitaitai. I’ve been meaning to get this space started for some time but, if I’m being honest, so many things have gotten in my way - and by many things I mean myself and the plethora of projects that I can’t seem to stop accruing. But as they say: there’s no better time than the present…so here we are!

item.title: Sources
item.description: Listan Tiningu’ A list of Chamoru resources that I frequent: Resource Notes Learning Chamoru Chamoru dictionary & lessons. Account required. Peter Onedera’s PDN Articles Siñot Onedera writes columns for the Guam PDN - every articles is in Chamoru & English! Chamorro Grammar by Sandra Chung. Downloadable PDF. Minagåhet Blog by Michael Lujan Bevacqua. General Chamoru knowledge. Påle’ Eric’s Blog by Påle’ Eric.

item.title: About Me
item.description: About David Taitingfong Håfa adai! Guahu si David Taitingfong — welcome to my blog! If you’re curious about why I started this blog, you can read about it in my first post. The tl;dr version is: I’m using this space to document my journey to learn Chamoru. That might change overtime, but for now it is what it is. In any case, if you’re looking for more info about me then look no further than the list below!
